ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I developed an insight into how monstrosity was constructed and how it intersected with imperialism throughout Europe's history.

Additionally, I improved my visual analysis skills.
I gained a lot of cultural and practical knowledge in this course! I also learned how to visually analyze artwork.

I learned how to perform visual analysis and breakdown a visual image to its most basic elements in order to better understand how everyday images inform my views of the world and can act to bias them, as well, so that I could be a better consumer of visual information. I also learned a lot about systems of category, and how they can inform views of otherness and monstrosity in art, and in the every day media, as well as the role of perspective.
A great overview of art from the time period as well as the role of monstrosity within it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would have loved to see more modern works discussed, and perhaps a more in-depth tracing of certain monsters/thoughts through the ages as a guideline to follow.

The teaching was a huge strength of this course. Nathalie and professor Fromont were incredible! I learned so much from them and they always encourages me to branch out and research things that interested me. I also appreciated that this class allowed us to explore so many assets this campus has to offer. I was able to visit more museums and collections in this class than I have in any other class.

I found the teaching style remarkably informative and both the professor and Natalie did a great job of engaging the students and making it a group-based discussion that engaged with topics that are relevant even today. I thought it was great how we got to take trips to the rare book museums and art museums to engage with the art in-person to discuss relevant topics while immersed. The teachers were well informed as to the topics, and had great teaching styles, and they chose interesting reading excerpts that were both relevant and thought-provoking, which aided class participation and interest. I cannot think of any weaknesses for the course or teachers as both teachers were great, and I enjoyed the course structure and topic.
Great professors who taught the course. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! When else are you going to take a class focused on monsters? Also, it gives you the opportunity to explore Yale's libraries and art museums in a way you may not have experienced prior.
Absolutely! This has been one of my favorite courses at Yale!

I think visual analysis is an under-appreciated skill in academics, which often only stresses textual analysis, so this course allowed us to develop these skill, while engaging with unique topics and perspectives about what makes a monster.

Yes I would if you are looking for an interesting seminar. The discussions were really thought-provoking. I am not an art history major but I still felt that a lot of the conversations that we had were relevant to other courses.
